case_name: Civil Appeal No. 287 of 1955 & Civil Appeal No. 288 of 1955 (State of Bombay & Anr. v. Plaintiff-Respondent)

facts.text: Two appeals are directed against the judgment and decree dated November 30, 1951 passed by Division Bench of High Court of Judicature at Bombay reversing District Judge at Miraj who dismissed plaintiffs suit for possession and mesne profits in Civil Suit No. 2 of 1940

anchor.surface_text: judgment and decree dated November 30, 1951, passed by a Division Bench of the High Court of Judicature at Bombay, reversing those of the District Judge at Miraj, dismissing the plaintiffs suit for possession and mesne profits in respect of the suit properties in Civil Suit No. 2 of 1940.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 287 of 1955 is on behalf of added respondent No. 7

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 287 of 1955, is on behalf of the added respondent No. 7, and the Civil Appeal No. 288 of 1955, is on behalf of the added respondent No. 6 - the State of Bombay

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 288 of 1955 is on behalf of added respondent No. 6 the State of Bombay representing original first defendant the Miraj State merged in State of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 288 of 1955, is on behalf of the added respondent No. 6 - the State of Bombay which number represents the original first defendant - the Miraj State  number merged in the State of Bombay .

facts.text: Plaintiff instituted suit on January 31, 1929 the last day of limitation in Munsiffs Court at Miraj registered as Original Suit No. 724 of 1930

anchor.surface_text: had instituted a suit on January 31, 1929, the very last day of limitation, in the Munsiffs Court at Miraj. This suit was registered as Original Suit No. 724 of 1930, in that companyrt.

facts.text: Suit for possession and mesne profits in respect of lands at Malgaon and Takli

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff prayed in the plaint for possession and mesne profits in respect of lands at Malgaon and Takli, on the ground that the then State of Miraj had wrongfully resumed those lands in 1910

facts.text: State of Miraj wrongfully resumed the lands in 1910 as part of State Sheri-Khata

anchor.surface_text: on the ground that the then State of Miraj had wrongfully resumed those lands in 1910, as part of the State Sheri-Khata, which, after inquiry, was ordered on July 31, 1915

facts.text: After inquiry lands ordered on July 31, 1915 to be recorded as State Sheri-Khata and usufruct appropriated to Khasgi-Khata of State

anchor.surface_text: as part of the State Sheri-Khata, which, after inquiry, was ordered on July 31, 1915, to be recorded as such lands, and the usufruct thereof during that period to be appropriated to the Khasgi-Khata of the State.

facts.text: Plaintiff impleaded State of Miraj as first defendant

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiff impleaded the State of Miraj as the first defendant.

facts.text: Defendants 2 and 3 are plaintiffs brothers who relinquished their interest in suit properties in favour of plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 2 and 3 are plaintiffs brothers who are said to have relinquished their interest in the suit properties in favour of the plaintiff.

facts.text: Defendants 4 to 7 belong to family of Narso who was recorded in respect of suit properties until his death in 1910 but did not appear and contest plaintiffs claim

anchor.surface_text: Defendants 4 to 7 belong to the family of Narso who was, until his death in 1910, recorded in respect of the suit properties, but they did number appear and companytest the plaintiffs claim.

facts.text: Suit valued at Rs. 2,065 being 5 times assessment on disputed lands for court-fee purposes

anchor.surface_text: The suit was valued at Rs. 2,065, being 5 times the assessment on the disputed lands for the purposes of companyrt-fee.

facts.text: No valuation given in plaint for purposes of jurisdiction with reference to value of properties claimed

anchor.surface_text: No valuation was given in the plaint for the purposes of jurisdiction with reference to the value of the properties claimed.

facts.text: Similar suit instituted by plaintiff in respect of lands in Tikoni village registered as Original Suit No. 443 of 1928 in Munsiffs Court at Miraj

anchor.surface_text: A similar suit had been instituted by the plaintiff in the same companyrt in respect of lands in another village called Tikoni. That had been registered as Original Suit No. 443 of 1928, in the Munsiffs companyrt at Miraj

facts.text: Tikoni suit dismissed on November 29, 1939

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the two suits proceeded in that companyrt in a very leisurely fashion until November 29, 1939, when the Tikoni suit was dismissed.

facts.text: Plaintiff made application on June 21, 1940 drawing attention that value of subject-matter not mentioned and on moderate valuation worth 8 to 10 thousand rupees so Munsiffs Court had no pecuniary jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: After the dismissal of that suit, the plaintiff made an application on June 21, 1940, drawing the attention of the companyrt to the fact that the value of the subject-matter of the suit had number been mentioned in the plaint

facts.text: Munsiffs Court allowed application and directed plaint returned on July 4, 1940

anchor.surface_text: The companyrt allowed the application and directed the plaint to be returned to be presented to the proper companyrt, on July 4, 1940.

facts.text: Plaint re-presented on July 4, 1940 to District Judge at Miraj numbered as Suit No. 2 of 1940

anchor.surface_text: The plaint was accordingly re-presented on that very date to the companyrt of District Judge at Miraj, and the same was numbered as Suit No. 2 of 1940.

facts.text: Original first defendant contested suit including plea of limitation

anchor.surface_text: The original first defendant only companytested the suit on a number of grounds, including the plea of limitation.

facts.text: Defendant petition dated October 27, 1942 that plaintiff knew value exceeded Munsiffs jurisdiction and act not bona fide

anchor.surface_text: By a petition dated October 27, 1942, the defendant brought it to the numberice of the companyrt that the plaintiff despite his knowledge that the value of the subject-matter of the suit was far in excess

facts.text: District Judge by judgment dated December 12, 1945 dismissed suit with costs

anchor.surface_text: After recording evidence and hearing the parties, the learned District Judge, by his judgment and decree dated December 12, 1945, dismissed the suit with companyts.

facts.text: On appeal State of Bombay added as 6th respondent and Yuvaraj of Miraj Madhavrao Narayanarao son of Raja Sahib added as 7th respondent as he acquired interest by grant

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the defeated plaintiff, during the pendency of the appeal, the State of Bombay was added as the 6th respondent, and the Yuvaraj of Miraj, Madhavrao Narayanarao, son of the Raja Sahib of Miraj, was added as the 7th respondent

facts.text: Appeal registered as First Appeal No. 104 of 1950 in High Court of Bombay

anchor.surface_text: The appeal was ultimately registered as First Appeal No. 104 of 1950, in the High Court of Bombay.

facts.text: Division Bench of Bombay High Court by judgment dated November 30, 1951 allowed appeal and decreed suit with costs against first and seventh respondents

anchor.surface_text: A Division Bench of that Court, by its judgment and decree dated November 30, 1951, allowed the appeal and decreed the suit with companyts against the first and the 7th respondents.

facts.text: Respondents 6 and 7 obtained certificate for leave to appeal to Supreme Court

anchor.surface_text: The respondents 6 and 7 aforesaid applied for and obtained the necessary certificate for companying up in appeal to this Court.

concepts.unlisted_description: Exclusion of time spent prosecuting suit in wrong court

anchor.surface_text: under Art. 142 of the Limitation Act, whether the cause of action arose in 1910, on the death of Narso aforesaid, or in 1915,

Before the promulgation, on January 1, 1926, of the Proclamation by State Karabhari, Miraj State, the law of limitation in that State, it is common ground, was that the plaintiff had the benefit of the period of 20 years as the period during which a suit for possession after dispossession could be instituted. By that Proclamation, the Indian Limitation Act IX of 1908 was made applicable to that State with effect from February 1, 1926, subject to this modification that all suits which would have been in time according to the old law of the State but would have become barred by limitation as a result of the introduction of the Indian Limitation Act, could be filed up to January 31, 1929, by virtue of certain modifications extending the last date for the institution of such suits. Hence, the suit filed on that date in the Munsiffs Court at Miraj, was admittedly within time, and was subject to the law of limitation under the Indian Limitation Act. When the plaint was returned by the Munsiffs Court at Miraj, at the instance of the plaintiff himself on the ground of want of pecuniary jurisdiction, and re-presented to the Court of the District Judge at Miraj on July 4, 1940, it was, on the face of it, barred by limitation, whether the period of limitation started to run in 1910 or 1915, unless the case is brought within section 14 of the Limitation Act.

Sub-section 1 of section 14 of the Limitation Act, which admittedly governs the present case, is in these terms - 1 . In computing the period of limitation prescribed for any suit, the time during which the plaintiff has been prosecuting with due diligence another civil proceeding, whether in a Court of first instance or in a Court of appeal, against the defendant, shall be excluded, where the proceeding is founded upon the same cause of action and is prosecuted in good faith in a Court which, from defect of jurisdiction, or other cause of a like nature, is unable to entertain it.

concepts.interpretation: Requires plaintiff to affirmatively prove four conditions: (1) prosecuting with due diligence the previous suit; (2) same cause of action; (3) prosecuted in good faith; (4) court unable due to defect of jurisdiction.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: t was unable to entertain that suit on account of defect of jurisdiction or other cause of a like nature. There is numberdispute between the parties h

anchor.surface_text: But the Indian Limitation Act contains its own definition of good faith to the effect that nothing shall be deemed to be done in good faith which is not done with due care and attention - section 2 7 .

concepts.interpretation: Good faith means done with due care and attention; distinguished from General Clauses Act's 'honestly whether negligently or not'.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: has to be remembered that it is number one of those cases which usually arise upon a revision of the valuation as given in the plaint, on an objectio

anchor.surface_text: they appear to have applied the definition of good faith as contained in the General Clauses Act, to the effect that A thing shall be deemed to be done in good faith where it is in fact done honestly, whether it is done negligently or not.

concepts.interpretation: Lower courts erroneously applied this broader definition instead of Limitation Act's stricter one.

anchor.surface_text: In order to bring his case within the section quoted above, the plaintiff has to show affirmatively 1 that he had been prosecuting with due diligence the previous suit in the court of the Munsif at Miraj, 2 that the previous suit was founded upon the same cause of action, 3 that it had been prosecuted in good faith in that court, and 4 that that court was unable to entertain that suit on account of defect of jurisdiction or other cause of a like nature.

anchor.surface_text: they appear to have applied the definition of good faith as contained in the General Clauses Act, to the effect that A thing shall be deemed to be done in good faith where it is in fact done honestly, whether it is done negligently or number. holdings.text: Both the courts below have viewed the controversy under section 14 of the Limitation Act, as if it was for the defendant to show mala fides on the part of the plaintiff when he instituted the previous suit and was carrying on the proceedings in that court. In our opinion, both the courts below have misdirected themselves on this question.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have viewed the controversy under section 14 of the Limitation Act, as if it was for the defendant to show mala fides on the part of the plaintiff when he instituted the previous suit and was carrying on the proceedings in that court. In our opinion, both the courts below have misdirected themselves on this question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Lower courts misdirected by treating issue as defendant's burden to prove mala fides rather than plaintiff's affirmative proof under s14.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Limitation Act s2(7) defines good faith strictly as with due care and attention, overriding broader General Clauses Act definition applied erroneously by lower courts.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, therefore, all the conditions necessary to bring the case within section 14, have not been satisfied by the plaintiff. There could be no doubt about the legal position that the burden lay on the plaintiff to satisfy those conditions in order that he may entitled himself to the deduction of all that period between January 31, 1929 and July 4, 1940.
The appeals are, accordingly, allowed and the suit dismissed with companyts throughout.

anchor.surface_text: There could be no doubt about the legal position that the burden lay on the plaintiff to satisfy those conditions in order that he may entitled himself to the deduction of all that period between January 31, 1929 and July 4, 1940. It is also clear that the courts below were in error in expecting the contesting defendant to adduce evidence to the contrary.
The appeals are, accordingly, allowed and the suit dismissed with companyts throughout.

anchor.surface_text: Both the courts below have viewed the controversy under section 14 of the Limitation Act, as if it was for the defendant to show mala fides on the part of the plaintiff when he instituted the previous suit and was carrying on the proceedings in that court. In our opinion, both the courts below have misdirected themselves on this question.
The appeals are, accordingly, allowed and the suit dismissed with companyts throughout.

anchor.surface_text: But the Indian Limitation Act contains its own definition of good faith to the effect that nothing shall be deemed to be done in good faith which is not done with due care and attention - section 2(7).
The appeals are, accordingly, allowed and the suit dismissed with companyts throughout.

anchor.surface_text: We have, therefore, to see if the institution and prosecution of the suit in the Munsiffs Court at Miraj, was done with due care and attention. We know that the plaint in the Tikoni suit filed by the same plaintiff in the same court, did contain a statement as to the value of the subject-matter, but it was conspicuous by its absence in the plaint in the suit
The appeals are, accordingly, allowed and the suit dismissed with companyts throughout.
The appeals are, accordingly, allowed and the suit dismissed with companyts throughout.
The appeals are, accordingly, allowed and the suit dismissed with companyts throughout.

In view of this conclusion, it is not necessary for us to pronounce upon the other contention raised on behalf of the appellants that, even after giving the benefit of section 14, the suit is still barred under Art. 142 of the Limitation Act.
